document.title: Early Childhood Education 1 Strands and Standards

55BA14E99C4A4388A48AE3F9255D1D66.description: Reflection/evaluation- a review of the activity including: any changes, children’s learning, teacher’s learning.

D1BD332D3F884C50A72CFF882444555D.description: Rationale- explains how the activity benefits the child

5DE6502411384045A85FC2D8B723423C.description: Supplies- materials needed to complete the activity

9F43A6F3054047C2B9127616BB2C842E.description: Procedure- Step by step instructions for implementing the activity

E589994339314EEB951948F8B9A97535.description: Standard- concise written descriptions of what students are expected to know and be able to do at a specific stage of their education. Age 3-5: https://www.schools.utah.gov/file/2f5c23cd-43cc-4ab1-b5d7-ef1f918362e9 Age 0-3: https://jobs.utah.gov/occ/provider/early_childhood.pdf

BEBC843A19BD4D5CA7E63BE188B28903.description: Objective- The overall goals that children may learn, know and/or do.

614E7288BFF24AE496F7E9D99FA49D74.description: Lesson Plan- A description of the activity that includes goals and procedure

F50EADAD5FB74AC5BDD5EF39367E42A5.description: Identify the components of a lesson plan.

F55EB3C93CA6442DB4754B0ADDEE88A1.description: Interactions with the children shall not include: restraining a child’s movement by binding, tying, or any other form of restraint that exceeds gentle, passive restraint

D609B6BB9AF74972ABC5A2CF9ECDBB7F.description: Individuals who interact with the children shall guide children’s behavior by using positive reinforcement, redirection and by setting clear limits that promote children’s ability to become selfdisciplined Caregivers shall use gentle, passive restraint with children only when it is needed to stop children from injuring themselves or others, or from destroying property

FF8AE785697442FBA2560FC6FA86DB8B.description: Inform parents, children and those who interact with the children of the center’s behavioral expectations and how any misbehavior will be handled

F037CD6BCA5243CB88CA4FB6EF3AA9E2.description: Any person who witnesses or suspects that a child has been subjected to abuse, neglect, or exploitation shall immediately notify Child Protective Services or law enforcement

A87A3E179E4340E09B27FCB4BE2B6A9D.description: Utah law requires any person who has reason to believe that a child has been subjected to abuse, neglect, or dependency to immediately to notify the nearest office of Child and Family Services, a peace officer, or a law enforcement agency.

33926CC70FD142FD996C9C4775A8FB42.description: Provider shall ensure that no child is subjected to physical, emotional, or sexual abuse while in care

4AB858029D3D47A9A5F5CA57EDCF83CF.description: Identify how best to challenge and support the children.

1D2C8DFD23FA45508D1D751C4677403D.description: Learn how to respond and interact with children.

89EA287D2C1D42C09BDF385D59D69B4B.description: Understand the child and their experience in the classroom.

467BF15831714A019FE1246E699599E5.description: Observation - Watching children with the clear goal of studying or understanding.

F316C5AA69E74808BDC59D1BA29B558E.description: Examine the purposes of observing children

CB2F9B93CE9F480E862B4DB93FBEB655.description:
Incorporate observation techniques and guidelines while studying children and developing strategies to
meet their needs.

9C4C7B8D1ABD448B8A8A2B51E7EA88E2.description: An area or time away where a child can calm down

5E26111A75F84005B563AEE4EA97A8EE.description: When children can make their own choices, even if it is within your limits, they not only get practice in making decisions, but they feel in control of the situation and are more willing to do what was asked

FFAA4EFF65B34CE7A55B75580B74CA24.description: Limit the number of options provided and be careful of the choices you give by making sure that you can really stand by it

EF1216171D39497AA6C2B184C6B5467D.description: Give children opportunities to make choices within the caregiver’s limits

C742FC285710483185FC8C855CEFA64B.description: Ex: sticker chart, reward system, praise etc.

46316D60F2584C84ADF6985ABE680F41.description: Ignore the negative behavior when possible and reinforce the positive behavior

B998E86E5F704574ABEBA220173D5610.description: Attention is a powerful reinforcement to guide children in a positive or negative direction

5D3FE5C94C214888BA9F64D8B1B01825.description: Some behaviors just need to be redirected to an appropriate place such as having a child jump on a trampoline instead of on the bed

B275668AD6C141C2B30796A7463BCC93.description: Children up to two years old can easily be distracted to change their behavior like playing with a toy instead of the electrical outlet

FEC640D7ABDC49D897B4DCFA5678F42A.description: Substituting unacceptable or dangerous behavior for acceptable behavior by helping the child to pay attention to or focus on something else that is equally or more appealing

D718631407DA4D33B1A1636E1CFE937A.description: To encourage a child to complete a task, tell them what needs to be done in short and simple steps (2 or 3 max) and then go and help them get started

E04B054022924521889B5071BD15F62C.description: When giving directions, get down on the child’s eye level to talk with them

5F79D00F30DD4FA697753565B52C7EC3.description: Clearly stating what the child IS expected to do instead of TELLING THEM WHAT NOT TO DO. i.e.: “Walk in the house” vs. “Don’t run in the house.”

3EEC92A4FD7E428FB41360B9A269B478.description: Adjust the environment so that items that might be a potential problem are placed out of sight

C8C054DF800D4B2A8DCC386AACF15BC4.description:
Respond to aggressive behavior in nonaggressive ways. i.e.: When responding to a 2-year-old having
a temper tantrum, if the caregiver remains calm and nonaggressive, then the situation becomes
deescalated and can be resolved quicker. If the child is going to harm themselves or someone else
remove them from the situation

5D34F28245474F7FA56AA87BF2D433E8.description: Discuss guidelines for using positive guidance techniques

BD07ED85694347C2A7372F08270C9693.description: State your expectations clearly and firmly, discuss limits in advance, use consequences as a form of discipline when expectations are not met, give the child explanations for your expectations and then listen to what they have to say about it.

9F7FC78817D744518F836D0D116E1EC1.description: Setting expectations with children means setting a guideline for behavior.

94801DB33F6342F4A7249B4D99607DCD.description:
Discuss reasons and guidelines for setting expectations. Review natural consequences in Child
Development.

4CCB0B20678F45ABB7B08D4552F97838.description: The need to feel that they belong

BD47F606A61F4C9698CD59579BF78DD7.description: They do not know any better

16942F65591C400A825EAB1B5E456EA7.description: Common behavior for the child’s development

3A67CE8FE3A444A8A325E4C761E80EFF.description: To be heard, understood, or validated

83615660EFCC4C2CA2982342A82D8F25.description:
All children’s behavior is a form of communication. Review common reasons for children’s behaviors. (Child
Development)

281EEED068634814A5DD9A62FCB56475.description: Self-discipline is the overall goal of guidance and discipline. The ability for the child or person to direct their own behavior and not to be directed upon

7E02B02278A343EBB541AF06224BD4EB.description: Distinguish between punishment and discipline/guidance techniques

F91A53E35DBF4E18AB461214FA66EB20.description:
Punishment: A penalty inflicted for wrongdoing, a crime or offense. Physical or verbal attacks. Might
teach obedience to authority (out of fear), but not self-control, which enhances self-respect. May
restrain a child temporarily, but it does not teach self-discipline. Demeans the child and negatively
affects the relationship

80CA53DE84E84D0CB0709F4A994D19B2.description: Discipline should be firm, fair and friendly.

9C98AED96F664A4F8BEC8DFE081F72A7.description: Discipline: to teach a behavior by instruction and exercise in accordance with rules of conduct.

AF634FDD706240E59BB5FC8003AAAD20.description: Positive Guidance: consistent ways of supporting children to identify express and regulate emotions, communicate needs with others, develop deep and trusting relationships.

0DA3098C001249BEB0B55FEC410ABC69.description: Define positive guidance, discipline, and punishment

19457A5C91614CD38B4B9438357B86C7.description: Explore the positive guidance techniques for preschoolers.

6634F116DF6F4E0CA6C043A55CD184E4.description: The end goal is for children to learn how to resolve conflicts on their own

66509A951DFD4465B6AEB8286FDF92F9.description: Help children see that a conflict is a shared problem that can be solved by seeing, listening to and understanding both points of view and finding a solution that everyone can agree upon

35994CF54B714D1AB1B290B543DD0552.description: Teach and model effective ways to resolve conflicts independently

128FC7C1479845949FBBD673D1473079.description: Help children interpret facial expressions in media and in others

086937577B374195A2C969D631D11CD9.description: Read books that allow you to discuss characters, feelings and actions

E014085305B5403796B6CB436AA80CF3.description: Help children put feelings into words

FBAC25468DD245FA9FFC68A5F778CF30.description: Teach, support and facilitate prosocial skills (compassion, empathy, sympathy, positive interactions, respect and support)

EF238436232B4586AD57B55050CFB03B.description: When communicating with children, staff and families state positive information before negative information

ABDFD4C3BD4A48ECAE62C1F2D4819B6A.description: Help children understand social rules, playing cooperatively, and contributing to a learning community

2D04839E31F44A36849E57A399A4DA2B.description: Let them know you care about, appreciate, and value them unconditionally

D9C1E94095D6426BAA2C135D1ACF3FB2.description: Validating children’s efforts, accomplishments, and progress not intellect

3A916E49C7334887B87DA6E3EC4483F8.description: Talking and listening to the child respectively

05FA86459AD54BEB9AB436E864C7EF04.description: Caregiver sets the example and expectations for how children relate to others by:

3BCDEEA722B94406AB0FDD29B7F32196.description: Develop a positive relationship with each child

7860FE47EE2744C6AE291EFC94D61D87.description: Students will guide children to function effectively in the group and to acquire social skills

0D16BDBC05AE4DD78B27726F9C50D2CE.description: Maintain confidentiality of any information families share

6E1C18A5422D43BB9A3A2FDD7EE56550.description: Hold parent-teacher conferences to discuss the child and center

DD24D91C66114ACDBB165304F6B3E3DF.description: Communicate with families by providing regular information concerning center business or happenings

15153CC013BC4BF9919F336989F6C4F4.description: Encourage family participation in the center

FE34E4EDE1DD441F96240AD8D1AC4AD5.description: Include pictures of families in the center

B6965D365E0945BCB483CF2D67DB8742.description: A partnership with families contributes to school success and provides a stable presence for the child

0D89EF256C144604A15800B87907F533.description: Develop a cooperative and collaborative relationship with families where you both make the interest of the child your focus

2B8A9AD1E21E45809F92161F69B70176.description: Family is a group of people, not necessarily biologically related that share emotional bonds, common values, goals, responsibilities and contribute significantly to each other’s well-being

6CD886C2BBA64FDA8CAE96E641925EE7.description: Reflectively recognizes and accepts the child’s thoughts and feelings. Repeat back to the child what they are feeling and saying.

41DD4363263C46E9BC787FA3C113CA1A.description: Active listening: Adult listens thoughtfully and carefully to a child does not offer solutions, does not criticize.

EFD5E935E9044528964CFF2FE42205EE.description: Give time, space and the means to work through their feelings; model calmness when discussing and dealing with feelings

C05DF94BACD540C3B7D2300EB498E952.description: Give permission to have all feelings, even negative and allow children to not feel ashamed

1C968C73FB904FB8AF664FFBD780417D.description: Teach children “feeling” words (happy, sad, excited, disappointed, etc.) and associate the name with a way they feel so they can articulate the feeling instead of acting out

63A8EA7C91B147329ACDE4A4094BED65.description: Guide children in expressing their feelings

085AA09C86A145E9ACA4BBA428C2B076.description: Resiliency: Ability to withstand, recover from, and adjust to set backs or change

5E48D9E4E2A54A6BA7304DEC9014AB19.description: Optimism: the belief that good things will happen to you and negative events are temporary setbacks to overcome

657E815778CC402F8DA51C73D76DA397.description: Personal power: Growth mindset vs. fixed mindset

9241F00369FB46D6BE67609A7F313548.description: Self-esteem: Perception of your own self-worth and value

B6D5DADC9F4C4A7B940463D1308237BD.description: Identity: Roles, behaviors and attributes that we assign ourselves

9D0EBCC7A42D4B05BB052A3CEC33F241.description: Promote a child’s sense of self and help them flourish

1B7B450D164D4E23BF2BCD6097A2D473.description: Support children in taking pride in their own individual and cultural identity

64BB2E772C564636B1276353D39F79DB.description: Temperament: how children approach, react to, and relate to the world around them

1C98C09E652842368E79302BCE45A7A4.description: Create experiences that support their sense of belonging

8D4BB96E997741909C49584715043768.description: Use observations to understand each child

1A796025A0F44AF0B9B919C30B6FFD7E.description: Students will develop a warm, positive, supportive and responsive relationship with each child

1CEBD678A1694157B52C508518C4975E.description: Students will support social and emotional development and implement positive guidance

7F1DB4894BFF48B697B518311588A896.description: Close-ended questions- questions that require only a “yes” or “no” response. These limit or end conversations, discussions and learning. Not an effective method unless it is followed by an open-ended question.

27A91F2F3CA543C8B5A208596959BB34.description: Open-ended questions- asking questions that require more than a yes or no answer, this is the ideal. Use the 5 W’s (who, what, where, when, why and how) to begin a question so children can answer with more description.

D50DB7F00BA1461CA7CC09F18FB7C951.description: Teacher directed- a teacher decides what to do and how to do it (i.e. circle time, teaching a new game, teacher directed steps, routines, etc.)

0562EF4ABB0343F099CA91C3EC1AF5B1.description: Child-directed or Child-initiated- a child decides what to do, the idea and the materials to use, the adult supports learning by following their lead

A35BE188DAF54AFBBADB931C04819D29.description: Explore the types learning strategies for children.

A0A7A46308E44E0A8D69B3F2E1FADBD3.description: Should not replace real hands on experiences

D322288D57D34FF9B19FDDD93EC33B1C.description: Expands children’s access to knowledge and skills

DA439A86522F4863AEC5BFD506C642CC.description:
Effective uses of technology and media by children are active, hands on, engaging and
impowering.

BF269AF9320949FAA85353ADF1B290C5.description: Technology and media can be valuable when used responsibly.

88837E2F436946A183FD20DFC0187D4A.description: Social Development Theory, Lev Vygotsky (Zone of Proximal Development)

92FEBA569FE94F3589543C5711607D56.description: Children need to be challenged just beyond their level of mastery

EB0F3666CF8F4696A69789AE5965332C.description: Theory of Multiple Intelligences, Howard Gardner

D493B6D8126D40F8B3CAB9A0B0595C56.description: Children learn in an integrated fashion that cuts across academic areas

A88AE7CEC6774C6982BED19350E6832D.description: Encourage each child’s sense of agency

5FBD7602A971421B9DB65EDB632326F9.description: Connections with home and community help children to feel psychologically safe

344ACB8463064335B5E2CEE88D1CF4EE.description: A sense of belonging requires both psychological and physical safety

AD1391B3051C4440A0F6C72FD24895B0.description: The environment can increase children’s motivation to learn

4930C2B51ECB48ABA1BB8902DC580BD4.description:
Passive learning- sitting and listening without interaction with others, the instructor or
manipulative objects (ex. puppet show)

A4343D0F05B145CD892FAECBDAF36AA9.description:
Active learning- being actively involved and engaged in the learning by doing, seeing and
thinking; it is handson and active

E9BDAE088AD74B339E6B1787CB3674AA.description: Children learn through active exploration and are complex thinkers

A6E715BA100D471787F251F09E90D4A3.description: Children are active learners from birth, creating meaning from their experiences

E33DBC7D7DFB4BA19B3912C353E46B00.description:
Development in learning occur at varying rates from child to child and uneven rates across
different areas for each child

C16B5A87A72140ACAD6100C883B9F4BF.description: Support children’s strengths and abilities(capability, potential or capacity)

0D6D2ED3A4DF40CB9D89D0B02921CBE9.description: Variations in culture, experience, and individuals must be considered

143C207A6F5D4ECB9D22ACF2EAE6D25D.description:
Cooperative- Children play cooperatively, adopt group goals, establish rules for play.
Cooperation is an advanced skill that children need support to learn.

BA4D67BF427B4F70A8992D043D658873.description:
Associative- children begin to be more interested in the other players. They can start to
use their newfound social skills to engage with other children or adults during an activity or
exploration.

F5526D2DB89444368D908DDE25858759.description:
Parallel- Children play next to each other but are not really interacting together. It’s like
a warm up exercise—children work side by side on the same activity, practicing skills and
learning new methods to engage together.

0BE806864DCB4608AB23AD9DD078D37D.description:
Onlooker- Children who sit back and engagingly watch other children playing, but do not
join in. Children learn about the social rules of play and relationships; they explore different
ways of playing or using materials and they learn about the world.

B1DD9D95C0704136A2496D95D09D41D6.description:
Solitary- Children entertain themselves without any other social involvement. They
can explore freely, master new personal skills like motor or cognitive skills, and prepare
themselves to play with others

C27526E5E4484DA78C84ADB68485A330.description:
Unoccupied- Children are relatively still and their play appears scattered. Allows children to
practice manipulating materials, mastering their self-control and learning about the world.

F8B1C1EF28E24640863BA92C35C14ED3.description: Mildred Parten’s Six Stages of Play

24A510FBA20C40EA82ACA6877738F1F4.description: Play facilitator- makes suggestions, asks questions, & supports social interactions in the play

BA8B8179E76B4FF8992EE11842330631.description: Play partner- participates in the play

85836FA3765D4899AFFFD27808E6816E.description: Roles of the teacher in play

43FCEAD709954763ADF658972781156B.description: Play is essential and promotes learning

66B47DD7D708404CA21379D7B20E0179.description: All domains of development are important and support others

133E86E3B5F340ABBAAD6117534107A5.description:
Serve and return- the two-way warm, responsive interaction between the child and the
caregiver.

714B37C2DDF14D20B3D52CD013F56BFA.description: Development is affected by biological and environmental factors

EA974291891E4ADB940D862D9C32F1AA.description: Nine Principles of child development and learning(see: naeyc.org)

63DC7F7FB8CF4E8E9805ADE4CAB20C23.description: Context in which development and learning occur

847518518F034BB1B5064C7FABE908B7.description: Individuality reflecting each child’s unique characteristics

E7168ABDFDD84626812BCA5DA9B54182.description: Commonality in children’s development and learning

10135D655B484F00BF2C4D6300072E4E.description:
Developmentally appropriate practice is designed to meet children “where they are, both as
individuals and as part of a group”

7FEB3DDA041F4B3FB6C91327B2C2B1A2.description: NAEYC- National Association for the Education of Young Children

C390221E8A854F778B4B8CCD7801B05C.description:
Methods that promote each child’s optimal development and learning through a strengths-based,
play-based approach to joyful, engaged learning.

9A514FCFBE89444F97AA4A9584DB8FBE.description: Identify developmentally appropriate (DAP) activities for young children.

E0A014DAA24A4AB3AD8E87ACA053004B.description: Review the domains of development (social, emotional, physical, and cognitive)

3CF1D9191D3641A8926820A8668E1513.description: Students will identify Developmentally Appropriate Practices (DAP).

AB086DDEC4AA427BA852179A4B5BB370.description:
Identify the career options in the early childhood field. Ex: Child life specialist, child care center worker,
elementary teacher/specialist, Headstart teacher/director, education coach, entrepreneur etc…

F2BF2026326341E4A031B173FEA04D30.description: Identify the advantages of furthering your education.

D1EF544605074774AC20319AFC23FEE3.description: Higher wage opportunities may be available

91286719401E483AB721F983B8B5D8FA.description: CDA observation with a Professional Development specialist (PD specialist)

B0B7F23333AE4CA7A486B23B2F871D01.description: Impact of childhood experiences now and on the future

BC29549B17114CEEBDF580B12544B022.description: Requirements for obtaining the Child Development Associate Credential (CDA)

7267634AD4284A17A47890719D066536.description: Identify the advantages of obtaining the Child Development Associate (CDA) credential

CAA90DC90688402FBFB91F5B4C439EAD.description: Identify the types of training and careers in the early childhood education industry.
